results_summary: Soy supplementation did not improve any outcomes, including quality of life, androgen deprivation symptoms, or metabolic risk factors.
population_specificity: Men with prostate cancer undergoing androgen deprivation therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the health benefits and mechanisms of action of genistein, a soy-derived isoflavonoid, in cancer prevention, chronic disease treatment, and cardioprotection.
results_summary: Genistein demonstrated antioxidant activity, cancer-suppressive effects, cardioprotection, reduced DNA damage, and modulation of immune responses. It also inhibited adipocyte differentiation and reduced apolipoprotein B secretion, suggesting benefits for hypercholesterolemia and atherogenic conditions.
population_specificity: Not specified (general cellular and molecular level effects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare feeding behaviors related to supplementary feeding with corn-soy blends (CSB) and lipid-based nutrient supplements (LNS) in children.
results_summary: LNS were more likely to be mixed into other foods, served with meals, and fed using an encouraging feeding style, while CSB were more often served unprepared and associated with forced feeding. The main differences were linked to how and when supplements were served.
population_specificity: 1,546 children aged 6 to 23 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the bioavailability and pharmacokinetics of isoflavones from two different soy supplement preparations in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in the pharmacokinetic parameters (AUC0-24/dose and Cmax/dose) of isoflavones between the two supplement preparations, suggesting variations in bioavailability that could impact health benefits.
population_specificity: Twelve healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: Same total isoflavones dose (specific amount not stated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the toxic effects of soy protein, particularly focusing on hormonal disturbances, carcinogenic potential, and organotoxicity, to raise public awareness.
results_summary: The review highlighted harmful effects of soy protein, including hormonal disturbances, carcinogenic risks, and organotoxicity, primarily focusing on the impact of soy isoflavone-genistein on various organs.
population_specificity: Not specified (clinical and experimental studies reviewed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a fixed combination of soy isoflavones affects the oral bioavailability of levothyroxine in post-menopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that soy isoflavones did not affect the rate or extent of levothyroxine absorption when taken concomitantly, as the pharmacokinetic parameters (Cmax and AUCt) fell within bioequivalence limits.
population_specificity: 12 healthy post-menopausal women on stable levothyroxine therapy for hypothyroidism.
effective_dosage: 60 mg of soy isoflavones (>19% genistin and daidzin) administered once.

study_goal: To determine whether a soy isoflavone supplement improves asthma control in adolescent and adult patients with poorly controlled asthma.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in lung function, symptom scores, or asthma control with soy isoflavone supplementation compared to placebo. Plasma genistein levels increased significantly in the supplement group, but this did not translate to clinical benefits.
population_specificity: Adults and children aged 12 or older with poorly controlled asthma and low dietary soy intake.
effective_dosage: 100 mg of total isoflavones daily, divided into 2 doses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of soy protein supplementation versus whey protein on body composition and nutritional status in Crohn's disease patients.
results_summary: Both soy and whey protein supplements similarly improved body composition by reducing body fat percentage and increasing lean body mass, with statistically significant changes in triceps skin fold thickness, mid-arm muscle circumference, and corrected arm muscle area. The study concluded that soy protein supplementation effectively contributes to controlling inflammation in Crohn's disease patients.
population_specificity: 68 Crohn's disease patients undergoing anti-TNF-alpha and azathioprine therapies (41 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a soy-containing lipid-based nutrient supplement (LNS/s) on plasma concentrations of antiretroviral drugs (efavirenz and nevirapine) in HIV-infected adults.
results_summary: The study found that the soy-containing LNS was associated with lower plasma nevirapine concentrations compared to no supplementation, but it did not affect efavirenz concentrations. The clinical relevance of the reduced nevirapine exposure remains unclear.
population_specificity: Ethiopian adult HIV-infected patients with a body mass index (BMI) > 17 kg/m².
effective_dosage: Daily supplementation (specific amount not detailed in the abstract).
study_duration: Plasma concentrations were measured at 1 and 2 months.
interactions: Possible interaction with nevirapine (reduced plasma concentrations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of soy isoflavone supplementation on blood pressure, hormonal levels, and symptom relief in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Soy isoflavone supplementation significantly reduced menopausal symptom severity (Kuppermann index), lowered FSH and LH levels, and slightly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (n=61, aged not specified)
effective_dosage: 33 g of soy (containing ~54 mg isoflavones) daily in biscuit form

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a need-based soy-protein nutritional supplement could improve physical functioning in undernourished older adults living in nursing homes.
results_summary: The soy-protein supplement significantly improved handgrip strength at weeks 12 and 24 and overall Barthel Index scores at week 24, suggesting enhanced physical functioning without adverse effects. The improvements were likely due to better nutritional status.
population_specificity: Older adults (≥65 years) living in a nursing home, non-bed-ridden, without acute infection, and able to self-feed or receive oral feeding.
effective_dosage: 50 g/day soy-protein-based supplement (containing 9.5 g protein and 250 kcal energy), administered when undernourished (Mini Nutritional Assessment score ≤24 and BMI ≤24 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the potential health and therapeutic benefits of lunasin, a soy-derived bioactive peptide.
results_summary: The study found that lunasin exhibits antioxidative, anti-inflammatory, anticancerous properties and may regulate cholesterol biosynthesis, with high bioavailability and heat stability suggesting its potential as a dietary supplement.
population_specificity: Not specified (general physiological functions in living beings).

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine if oral soy protein supplementation during dialysis reduces inflammation and improves physical function and body composition in maintenance hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: Six months of soy supplementation significantly reduced interleukin 6 levels, showed a trend for reduced C-reactive protein, and improved gait speed and shuttle walk test performance, though no changes in body composition were observed. Alkaline phosphatase, a bone turnover marker, was also reduced.
population_specificity: Maintenance hemodialysis patients aged ≥30 years, receiving treatment ≥3 days/week for ≥3 months, without congestive heart failure or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a soy-based dietary supplement, low-dose hormone therapy, and placebo on urogenital symptoms in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The soy supplement improved vaginal dryness but did not show estrogenic effects on the urogenital tract. No significant changes were observed in urinary or sexual symptoms, and adverse effects were similar across all groups.
population_specificity: 60 healthy postmenopausal women aged 40-60 years (mean time since menopause: 4.1 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether isolated daidzein and genistein, components of soy, improve glycemic control and insulin sensitivity in women with impaired glucose regulation.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in glycemic control or insulin sensitivity between the groups receiving soy protein alone, soy protein with daidzein, or soy protein with genistein over 24 weeks. Neither daidzein nor genistein showed a measurable effect on glucose or insulin metrics.
population_specificity: Chinese women aged 30-70 with impaired glucose regulation (IGR).
effective_dosage: 10 g of soy protein daily, with or without 50 mg of daidzein or 50 mg of genistein.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the effects of soy isoflavone (SIF) supplementation on improving cognitive function in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found a statistically significant positive effect of SIF supplementation on summary cognitive function and visual memory in postmenopausal women, with stronger effects observed in non-US countries, younger age groups, and shorter treatment durations.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of soy supplementation on breast cancer-related genes and pathways in women with early-stage breast cancer.
results_summary: Soy supplementation led to increased plasma isoflavones and altered expression of 21 genes, including those related to cell cycle and proliferation, but did not significantly change Ki67 or Cas3 levels. The findings suggest soy may adversely affect gene expression in breast cancer.
population_specificity: Women (n = 140) with early-stage breast cancer.
study_duration: 7 to 30 days, from diagnosis until surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a soy dietary supplement on cardiovascular health biomarkers in postmenopausal women against low-dose hormone therapy and placebo.
results_summary: The soy dietary supplement showed no significant changes in cardiovascular biomarkers (lipid profile, glucose, blood pressure, etc.) compared to placebo, while hormone therapy reduced total and LDL cholesterol.
population_specificity: 60 healthy postmenopausal women aged 40-60, mean 4.1 years since menopause.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of soy protein versus whey protein in lipid-based nutritional supplements on lean body mass, grip strength, and immune recovery in HIV patients starting antiretroviral treatment.
results_summary: Soy supplementation increased lean body mass by 0.97 kg and grip strength by 0.93 kg compared to controls, with no significant effects on immune recovery. The effects of soy and whey supplements were not significantly different in direct comparison.
population_specificity: Adults with HIV (BMI >16) in Ethiopia, predominantly women (66%), mean age 33.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the relationship between isoflavone intake from soy foods and supplements and plasma concentrations to aid in risk assessment for potential adverse effects.
results_summary: The study found that doubling isoflavone intake increased plasma concentrations by 55-62% for most isoflavones, with significant inter-individual variation (30-96%). Equol producers had higher plasma concentrations than non-producers.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a fortified blended food (wheat-soy-blend++, WSB++) on linear growth and stunting in children compared to other supplements and a control group.
results_summary: WSB++ did not significantly impact linear growth (LAZ) or weight-for-length z-score (WLZ) compared to the control group, whereas other supplements showed modest benefits. The prevalence of stunting was not reduced by WSB++.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-18 months in rural Bangladesh.
effective_dosage: Daily supplementation for a year (exact amount not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of child-centered counseling (CCC) with soy-based supplements (CSB++ and RUSF) in treating moderate acute malnutrition (MAM) in children.
results_summary: The study found that soy-based supplements (CSB++ and RUSF) were significantly more effective than CCC in achieving recovery from MAM, with recovery rates of 74.5% and 74.2%, respectively, compared to 57.8% for CCC. However, when adjusted for attendance, no significant difference was observed between the three interventions.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-24 months with uncomplicated MAM in rural health centers.
effective_dosage: 455 g CSB++ or 350 g soy-based RUSF weekly, providing ~250 kcal/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a corn-soy blend plus (CSB+) against a more expensive ready-to-use supplementary food (RUSF) in improving health outcomes for HIV patients on antiretroviral therapy.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in BMI, household wealth, hunger, general health perception, or ART adherence between the CSB+ and RUSF groups at 6 or 12 months. The RUSF group showed a higher CD4 count at 12 months, but this difference was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: HIV-infected adults on antiretroviral therapy in rural Haiti.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to comprehensively evaluate the scientific evidence regarding the health benefits and risks of soy consumption, focusing on specific conditions like menopausal symptoms, heart disease, cancer, and thyroid function.
results_summary: Soy foods and isoflavones may relieve menopausal symptoms and protect against breast cancer and heart disease, but do not appear to prevent osteoporosis. Effects on male fertility and thyroid function were inconsistent, and processing methods may reduce antinutrient content.
population_specificity: General human population, with specific mentions of menopausal women, males, and individuals at risk for thyroid dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antiobesity and antioxidant effects of doenjang (fermented soybean paste) in overweight Koreans with the PPAR-γ2 C1431T polymorphism.
results_summary: Doenjang supplementation significantly reduced visceral fat area in subjects with the mutant T allele, improved antioxidant capacity (ORAC, DNA tail length) in those with the C allele, and increased catalase activity in the C allele group. However, plasma free fatty acids, insulin, and HOMA-IR levels increased in the doenjang group.
population_specificity: Overweight Koreans with PPAR-γ2 C1431T polymorphism (n=51 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the long-term effects of soy protein and/or soy isoflavones on serum lipids and inflammatory markers in postmenopausal women, hypothesizing that combined supplementation would most improve coronary heart disease risk factors.
results_summary: The study found no significant effects on serum lipids or inflammatory markers in the overall population, though equol producers showed modest improvements in cholesterol ratios. Soy protein and isoflavones, alone or combined, were not effective for lipid modification in non-equol-producing postmenopausal women.
population_specificity: Healthy ambulatory women older than 60 years (late postmenopausal).
effective_dosage: 18 g/d soy protein and/or 105 mg/d isoflavone aglycone equivalents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fructooligosaccharides (FOS) supplementation could increase equol production in equol producers and stimulate equol production in non-producers among Japanese postmenopausal women consuming soy isoflavones.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of FOS supplementation on serum equol concentration or urinary equol-to-daidzein ratios in either equol producers or non-producers after 2 weeks. A transient interaction effect was observed after 1 week but was not sustained.
population_specificity: Healthy postmenopausal Japanese women (34 completed the study, 21 equol producers and 13 non-producers).
effective_dosage: 37 mg isoflavone conjugates (21 mg aglycone form) daily, with 5 g/day FOS or sucrose as control.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether black soy peptide supplementation could reduce blood pressure and oxidative stress in individuals with prehypertension or stage I hypertension.
results_summary: The study found that black soy peptide supplementation significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure compared to controls, along with decreased oxidative stress markers (MDA and urinary 8-epi-prostaglandin F2α) and increased antioxidant activity (SOD and NO). Changes in blood pressure negatively correlated with changes in nitric oxide levels.
population_specificity: 100 participants with untreated systolic blood pressure (130-159 mm Hg) or diastolic blood pressure (80-99 mm Hg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of whole soy foods (soy flour) and purified daidzein on anthropometric measurements and body composition in prehypertensive, equol-producing postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that neither whole soy nor purified daidzein significantly affected body weight, BMI, waist and hip circumferences, WHR, body fat percentage, fat mass, or free fat mass compared to a placebo.
population_specificity: Prehypertensive, equol-producing postmenopausal women.
effective_dosage: 40 g soy flour daily (whole soy group), 40 g low-fat milk powder + 63 mg daidzein daily (daidzein group), or 40 g low-fat milk powder daily (placebo group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a soy protein-based supplement combined with endurance training on endurance capacity, metabolic function, and inflammatory markers in healthy sports students.
results_summary: The study found that the soy protein supplement group showed significant improvements in running velocity, lower lactate levels, and better metabolic function post-exercise, though no changes in body composition or inflammatory markers were observed.
population_specificity: Healthy sports students (10 males and 5 females per group, aged 23.6 ± 1.9 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether soy isoflavone supplementation improves quality of life in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in Menopause-Specific Quality of Life domain scores at 1 and 2 years compared to baseline, with no differences among treatment groups. Soy isoflavone supplementation showed no benefit for quality of life in postmenopausal women.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (n=403)
effective_dosage: 80 or 120 mg of daily aglycone hypocotyl soy isoflavone

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a need-based soy-protein-based nutritional supplement could improve the nutritional status of elderly nursing home residents at risk of undernourishment.
results_summary: The intervention significantly improved body weight, BMI, mid-arm circumference, calf circumference, and serum albumin and cholesterol concentrations, but did not significantly affect hematocrit, hemoglobin, or lymphocyte count. The strategy was deemed practical and useful for improving nutritional status in nursing home residents.
population_specificity: Elderly (≥65 years) nursing home residents in Taiwan with BMI ≤25 kg/m², able to self-feed or receive oral feeding, without acute infection, and non-bed-ridden.
effective_dosage: 50g/day soy-protein-based supplement (containing 9.5g protein, 250kcal energy, and essential micronutrients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of soy isoflavone supplementation on body weight, fasting glucose, and insulin levels in non-Asian postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in body weight, fasting glucose, and fasting insulin levels with soy isoflavone supplementation, particularly in shorter durations (<6 months) for weight loss and longer durations (≥6 months) for glucose control. Greater effects were observed in normal-weight women compared to obese women.
population_specificity: Non-Asian postmenopausal women
effective_dosage: Lower dose subgroup (<100 mg) showed more reduction in body weight.
study_duration: Varied, with some studies <6 months and others ≥6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether black soy peptide supplementation could reduce body weight and body fat in overweight/obese subjects.
results_summary: The study found that black soy peptide supplementation significantly reduced body weight, BMI, body fat mass, and leptin levels in overweight/obese subjects after 6 and 12 weeks, with no significant changes observed in the placebo group. Fasting insulin levels also decreased significantly in the test group.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese subjects (n = 80 randomized, n = 64 completed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a natural S-equol supplement on metabolic parameters in overweight or obese individuals, particularly focusing on glycaemic control and cardiovascular disease prevention.
results_summary: The study found that natural S-equol supplementation significantly reduced HbA1c, LDL-C levels, and CAVI scores, with more pronounced effects in female equol non-producers. The ratio of equol non-producers was higher in overweight/obese subjects compared to the general population.
population_specificity: 54 Japanese overweight or obese outpatients (BMI ≥ 25 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of S-equol (a soy metabolite) with soy isoflavones in relieving menopausal symptoms, particularly hot flashes and muscle/joint pain.
results_summary: The study found that 40 mg/day S-equol reduced hot flash frequency more than isoflavones, especially in women experiencing >8 hot flashes/day. Lower doses (10-20 mg/day) improved muscle and joint pain more effectively than isoflavones.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 45-65 experiencing ≥5 hot flashes/day.
effective_dosage: 10, 20, or 40 mg S-equol/day or soy isoflavones (dosage unspecified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of soy isoflavones on preventing osteoporosis and identify the effective dosage and duration of supplementation.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that soy isoflavones significantly increased bone mineral density by 54% and decreased the bone resorption marker urinary DPD by 23%, with stronger effects in postmenopausal women and doses above 75 mg/d. No significant effect was observed on bone formation markers.
population_specificity: Women, particularly postmenopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of soy-derived isoflavone on blood glucose, lipid profiles, and sex hormones related to cardiovascular disease in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that 70 mg/day of soy isoflavone for 12 weeks significantly reduced triglyceride (TG) levels and luteinizing hormone (LH) but did not affect fasting glucose, insulin, HOMA-IR, TC, LDL-C, HDL-C, FFA, FSH, estrone, or estradiol.
population_specificity: Korean postmenopausal women with FSH levels >40 IU/ml.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effects of soy product consumption on serum lipid profiles and glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: Soy product intake significantly reduced serum total cholesterol, triacylglycerol, and low-density lipoprotein-cholesterol while increasing high-density lipoprotein-cholesterol, but had no significant effects on fasting glucose, insulin, or glycated hemoglobin.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the antiobesity effect of doenjang (fermented soy paste) differed based on the UCP-1 gene polymorphism in overweight subjects.
results_summary: Doenjang supplementation significantly reduced visceral fat and increased free fatty acid concentrations in subjects with the G allele of the UCP-1 polymorphism, but had no significant effect on visceral fat overall compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Overweight subjects (BMI ≥23 kg/m², waist-to-hip ratio ≥0.90 for men or ≥0.85 for women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether soy isoflavone supplementation reduces breast epithelial proliferation and other biomarkers in healthy high-risk women, suggesting potential for breast cancer prevention.
results_summary: The study found no significant reduction in breast epithelial proliferation with soy isoflavone supplementation, and a possible adverse increase in proliferation among premenopausal women. No treatment effect was observed on cytologic atypia or nipple aspirate fluid parameters, though gene expression changes were noted in the soy group.
population_specificity: Healthy, high-risk adult Western women (pre- and postmenopausal).
effective_dosage: Mixed soy isoflavones (PTIG-2535) – exact dosage not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether soy supplement use was associated with health-related quality of life (HRQOL), fatigue, or hormone-related symptoms in breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: Soy supplement users were more likely to have a better physical health summary score (OR = 1.66, 95% CI = 1.02-2.70), but no associations were found with fatigue or hormone-related symptoms.
population_specificity: 767 breast cancer survivors participating in the Health, Eating, Activity, and Lifestyle (HEAL) Study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a public-private partnership in delivering a soy-based micronutrient powder (YYB) to reduce anaemia and improve child growth and feeding practices.
results_summary: The study found that 59.6% of caregivers purchased YYB, and while anaemia prevalence reduction was not statistically significant overall, those who purchased YYB saw an 87% reduction in anaemia risk. Feeding practices also improved significantly after the intervention.
population_specificity: Caregivers and their 6- to 24-month-old children in China.
effective_dosage: Not specified (product sold at 0.1 USD per unit, exact dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare developmental outcomes in infants receiving lipid-based nutrient supplements versus micronutrient-fortified corn-soy porridge.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in developmental outcomes between infants receiving corn-soy porridge and those receiving lipid-based supplements. Maternal education and length-for-age z-score gain were associated with developmental outcomes.
population_specificity: 163 six-month-old rural Malawian children

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if seaweed could modify soy-associated increases in IGF-1 serum concentrations in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Soy significantly increased serum IGF-1 concentrations, but concurrent seaweed consumption reduced this increase by about 40%. The combination of seaweed and soy was effective in mitigating the IGF-1 elevation caused by soy alone.
population_specificity: Thirty healthy postmenopausal women (mean age 58 years).
effective_dosage: 2 mg/kg body weight aglycone equivalent isoflavones (high-soy protein isolate powder).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence regarding the efficacy of herbal and dietary supplements, including soy, on cognitive function in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Five of the twelve RCTs suggested that soy supplementation may improve cognition in postmenopausal women, but most studies had serious methodological flaws, making the evidence not compelling.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether soy germ isoflavones could alleviate menopausal symptoms and improve lipid profiles in early postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Soy germ isoflavones (84 mg and 126 mg daily) significantly reduced hot flush frequency and Kupperman index scores compared to placebo, but no significant effects were observed on lipid profiles or female hormone levels.
population_specificity: Early postmenopausal Chinese women aged 45-60 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of equol, a soy isoflavone metabolite, on bone metabolism and hormone levels in non-equol-producing postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Equol supplementation increased equol levels dose-dependently, significantly reduced bone resorption markers, and prevented bone mineral density loss at 10 mg/day, with no adverse effects on hormone levels.
population_specificity: Non-equol-producing postmenopausal Japanese women.
effective_dosage: 2 mg/day, 6 mg/day, and 10 mg/day of equol supplement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of black soy peptide supplementation on glucose control in subjects with prediabetes and newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: Black soy peptide supplementation showed a tendency to lower fasting glucose levels and a significant reduction in 2-hour postload glucose levels, though hemoglobin A1c levels were not significantly improved.
population_specificity: Subjects with prediabetes (impaired fasting glucose or impaired glucose tolerance) and newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes mellitus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-dose isoflavone supplements could lower PSA levels in men with low-volume prostate cancer.
results_summary: The study found that high-dose isoflavone supplements significantly increased serum concentrations of genistein and daidzein but did not lower PSA levels in men with prostate cancer. No changes in PSA were observed after 6 or 12 months of supplementation.
population_specificity: 53 men with prostate cancer enrolled in an active surveillance program.
effective_dosage: 450 mg genistein, 300 mg daidzein, and other isoflavones daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether isoflavone soy protein (ISP) supplementation reduces subclinical atherosclerosis progression in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: ISP supplementation did not significantly reduce atherosclerosis progression overall but showed a potential benefit in women within 5 years of menopause, with a 68% lower progression rate compared to placebo. No major adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 45-92 without diabetes or cardiovascular disease.
effective_dosage: 25 g soy protein (containing 91 mg aglycon isoflavone equivalents) divided into two daily doses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if soy isoflavones could reduce the adverse effects of radiation therapy in prostate cancer patients while enhancing its efficacy.
results_summary: Soy isoflavones reduced urinary, bowel, and sexual adverse symptoms compared to placebo, with improvements in urinary incontinence, urgency, erectile function, and bowel-related pain. The effects were more pronounced at 6 months than at 3 months.
population_specificity: 42 patients with localized prostate cancer undergoing radiation therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether corn-soy blend (CSB) or lipid-based nutrient supplements (LNS) improved weight gain in moderately underweight African children.
results_summary: LNS modestly increased weight gain compared to controls, particularly in children with lower initial weight-for-age Z-scores, while CSB showed no significant difference from controls.
population_specificity: Moderately underweight (WAZ < -2) 6- to 15-month-old African children.
effective_dosage: 71 g/d CSB (921 kJ) or 43 g/d LNS (1189 kJ).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of dietary soy supplementation, low-dose hormone therapy, and placebo on psychological, somatic, and urogenital symptoms in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Soy supplementation significantly improved somatic symptoms (hot flashes, muscle pain) and urogenital symptoms (vaginal dryness) compared to placebo, with effects comparable to hormone therapy. No significant differences were found in psychological symptoms or overall MRS score between groups.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 40-60 years with menopausal symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of soy isoflavones on glucose metabolism (fasting blood glucose, insulin, and insulin resistance) in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Soy isoflavones did not significantly affect fasting blood glucose but showed a beneficial effect on insulin levels and insulin resistance, particularly with genistein. Subgroup analyses indicated differing effects based on the type of isoflavone used.
population_specificity: Non-Asian perimenopausal and postmenopausal women not taking hormone therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a combination of sago and soy protein ingested during moderate-intensity cycling could improve subsequent high-intensity endurance capacity compared to sago alone or a placebo.
results_summary: The sago-soy combination significantly increased endurance by 84% compared to placebo and 37% compared to sago alone, with statistically significant results (p < .001 and p < .05, respectively). Plasma insulin response was elevated during sago and sago-soy supplementation.
population_specificity: 8 male recreational cyclists (age 21.5 ± 1.1 yr, weight 63.3 ± 2.4 kg, VO2max 39.9 ± 1.1 ml·kg⁻¹·min⁻¹).
effective_dosage: 52.5 g carbohydrate and 15 g soy protein, administered at 20-min intervals during exercise.
study_duration: Single session (60 min moderate-intensity cycling followed by time-to-exhaustion test).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of soy-derived isoflavones on hot flushes, menopausal symptoms, and mood in climacteric women with increased BMI.
results_summary: Soy isoflavone supplementation significantly reduced hot flushes (frequency and severity), improved menopausal symptoms (MRS scores), and decreased depressive mood (HDRS scores) after three months. No significant changes were observed in blood pressure or BMI.
population_specificity: Climacteric women aged 40-59 with increased BMI (≥ 25).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether soy (as dietary supplement, extract, or isoflavone concentrate) reduces the incidence of hot flashes in climacteric women compared to placebo.
results_summary: The study found a significant but modest reduction in hot flashes favoring soy, with standardized mean differences of -0.39 overall and varying effects by subgroup (-0.45 for concentrate, -0.51 for extract, -0.20 for dietary supplement). However, high heterogeneity among studies made conclusive results difficult to establish.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women experiencing hot flashes attributed to the climacterium (without a cancer background).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of soy protein consumption on heart disease risk in postmenopausal women, focusing on lipid profile alterations.
results_summary: The study found no significant cardiovascular benefits from soy protein supplementation, with mixed lipid profile changes—some unfavorable (increased Apo B, decreased Apo A) and others neutral (no significant LDL or triglyceride changes).
population_specificity: Moderately hypercholesterolemic postmenopausal women (n=62).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare feeding patterns and behaviors between undernourished children receiving corn-soy blend (CSB) versus lipid-based nutrient supplements (LNS) and assess associations with child growth.
results_summary: No significant differences were found in feeding episodes or daily feeding time between CSB and LNS groups. Caregivers used spoons, washed hands, and had leftovers more often with CSB, suggesting serving mode influenced outcomes. Leftovers were negatively associated with child weight-for-age Z-score (WAZ) changes.
population_specificity: Undernourished children aged 6-17 months in southern Malawi.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic potential of Soy Isoflavones (SI) in treating osteosarcoma (OS) and to explore the underlying mechanisms, particularly focusing on mitophagy.
results_summary: SI dose-dependently inhibited proliferation, migration, and invasion of U2OS cells while enhancing apoptosis and inducing mitophagy. These effects were mediated by blocking the AKT/mTOR pathway, and the anti-tumor effects were confirmed in a mouse xenograft model.
population_specificity: U2OS osteosarcoma cells and a mouse tumor xenograft model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the mechanisms of action of soy isoflavones (genistein, daidzein, and equol) in reducing cancer risk, particularly prostate cancer, at the cellular level.
results_summary: The study found that soy isoflavones, especially genistein, daidzein, and equol, exhibit multiple anticancer mechanisms, including modulation of hormone-mediated pathways, regulation of cell proliferation, apoptosis, angiogenesis, metastasis, and antioxidant/anti-inflammatory effects. These effects were observed in vitro and in vivo, particularly in prostate cancer.
population_specificity: Asian populations (with noted interest in prostate cancer risk reduction).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the effects of soy isoflavone supplements on bone turnover markers, particularly urinary deoxypyridinoline (DPD) and serum bone alkaline phosphatase (BAP), in menopausal women.
results_summary: Soy isoflavone supplementation significantly decreased the bone resorption marker DPD by 18.0% compared to placebo but had no significant effect on bone formation markers BAP and osteocalcin (OC). The effects varied between studies, indicating the need for further research.
population_specificity: Menopausal women
effective_dosage: Average 56 mg (for DPD effects), about 84 mg (for BAP effects), and 73 mg (for OC effects) of soy isoflavones (aglycone equivalents) daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the potential of soy isoflavones to reduce depression in middle-aged women by examining their effects on serotonin pathways linked to fluctuating estrogen levels.
results_summary: The study found that soy isoflavones may support serotonin synthesis and availability by influencing TPH-2 and MAO-A, but effects on SERT and serotonin receptors were inconsistent. Results on their effectiveness in reducing depressive symptoms varied widely.
population_specificity: Middle-aged (peri)menopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a combination of soy isoflavones, 8-PN, and melatonin on reducing hot flashes and improving quality of life in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in quality of life scores and reductions in hot flashes at 4 and 12 weeks, with progressive benefits over time. The supplement combination effectively improved vasomotor, psychosocial, and physical domains.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women suffering from moderate-to-severe hot flashes (≥5 daily or ≥35 weekly).
effective_dosage: 54.4 mg standardized soy isoflavones (including 24.5 mg genistein and 16.3 mg daidzein), 100 µg 8-PN, and 1 mg melatonin once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the microbial metabolite profiles of soy isoflavones (daidzein and genistein) in postmenopausal women and classify them into different metabotypes based on their metabolite profiles and estimated estrogenic potency.
results_summary: The study identified 5 distinct isoflavone metabotypes based on urinary metabolite profiles, which varied significantly in their metabolite composition and estimated estrogenic potency. The findings suggest that individual differences in gut microbiota metabolism influence the effects of soy isoflavones.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of soy isoflavones (SIs) on genomic instability (GIN) in normal and cancerous human colon cells.
results_summary: Soy isoflavones (3.125-50 μM) showed no difference in promoting GIN between normal colon cells (NCM460) and colon cancer cells (SW620). When combined with curcumin, SIs promoted proliferation and GIN in both cell types, but no synergistic effect was observed.
population_specificity: Human normal colon cells (NCM460) and colon cancer cells (SW620).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the potential role of soy isoflavones as a nutritional adjuvant in the prevention and treatment of NAFLD in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The abstract suggests promising evidence supporting the potential benefits of soy isoflavones for NAFLD prevention and treatment in postmenopausal women, though further research is needed to confirm effectiveness in alleviating hepatic steatosis.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with or at risk of NAFLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between soy food and isoflavone intake with ovarian reserve markers in individuals presenting to a fertility center.
results_summary: The study found no significant association between soy or isoflavone intake and ovarian reserve markers (AFC, AMH, FSH) in most analyses, except for a slight decrease in AMH levels in the highest soy intake group.
population_specificity: Patients presenting to an academic fertility center between 2007 and 2019 (667 participants).
effective_dosage: Median intake of soy was 0.09 servings/day and isoflavones was 1.78 mg/day.
study_duration: Intake was assessed over the previous 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the molecular interaction between isoflavone glucosides (from soy-based supplements) and G-tetrads (guanosine/deoxyguanosine tetrads) to understand their potential role in cancer therapy.
results_summary: The study found that glycitin had the strongest interaction with [4G+Na]+ ions, and isoflavone glucosides generally bound more strongly to guanosine tetrads than deoxyguanosine tetrads. These interactions were measured using ESI-CID-MS and survival yields method.
population_specificity: Not specified (molecular-level study, no human participants)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether soy isoflavones reduce fibroglandular breast tissue (FGBT), a biomarker for breast cancer risk, in premenopausal women.
results_summary: Soy isoflavones induced a time- and concentration-dependent decrease in FGBT and FGBT%, with greater effects observed in adherent subjects. The study also noted moderate interactions between calcium, BMI, and breast fat composition.
population_specificity: Premenopausal women aged 30-42 years.
effective_dosage: 136.6 mg as aglycone equivalents, consumed 5 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of soy isoflavones in bone homeostasis and their effects on the RANK/RANKL/OPG pathway.
results_summary: Soy isoflavones were found to decrease RANKL levels and increase OPG levels, potentially improving bone metabolism and reducing resorption, though some studies reported no significant changes in these markers. Current evidence is insufficient for conclusive approval of their efficacy on the RANKL/RANK/OPG pathway.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of available evidence)
